awd_titl_txt: Development of a Competency-Based Education Program in CyberSecurity
awd_abstract_narration:
To address the demand for highly skilled workers who are prepared to protect the critical national cyber infrastructure as well as the call for greater student completion rates of a postsecondary degree or certificate, this project at Lincoln Land Community College (LLCC) in Illinois is designed to create a competency based education (CBE) program in cybersecurity. Working with industry and education partners, LLCC will plan, develop and implement this learner-focused CBE program that will increase completion rates while potentially reducing the time and the cost to students. The program will build upon the current knowledge base of each individual student and eliminate unnecessary time and effort on learning objectives already mastered. Because there is limited research for CBE programs developed within existing higher education structures, this project includes a comprehensive evaluation component. Because many institutions in postsecondary education and especially community colleges are looking for innovators who have paved the path in CBE and are seeking advice for best practices and program implementation to better serve their students, LLCC will be positioned to share best practices and data regarding participation and completion to both state and national organizations. Deployed military can use the CBE program to build upon their current knowledge and complete the program entirely off campus as a result of virtual technology. Since LLCC serves a large rural population, this competency-based program will address the barriers faced by rural students wishing to participate in opportunities related to this vital science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) field. 

The project objectives are to provide an alternative delivery model for attaining a cybersecurity certificate by: 1) developing curriculum based on competency driven assessments to deliver a CBE cybersecurity certificate program, 2) developing an effective student admission process for evaluating student skills and behaviors needed to be successful in a competency-based program, 3) developing support services for students including advising, financial aid, and coaching to ensure success and completion in the program, 4) implementing the CBE cybersecurity certificate, and 5) evaluating the process and outcomes of the CBE cybersecurity certificate program. LLCC will contribute course content to the ATE Center for Systems Security and Information Assurance (CCSIA) at Moraine Community College and the ATE National CyberWatch Center at Prince George's Community College as well as adapt many of their materials for a rural audience. Completion pathways for this program will include a certificate and upon completion of the certificate the student can enter the workforce or continue their educational endeavors. The certificate is a building block to receiving an associate degree, which the student can use to transfer to a four year institution to complete a baccalaureate degree. This program will provide promising opportunities for students (both local and rural), not only at the post-secondary level, but also at the secondary level through dual credit offerings or dual enrollment at the community college.

por.por_cntn:
This completed project at Lincoln Land Community College (LLCC) in Springfield, Illinois provides a Competency Based Education (CBE) program in Cybersecurity.  It addresses the demand for highly skilled workers prepared to protect the National Cybersecurity infrastructure. With input from industry partners, this twelve-course certificate assures rigor, reduces program completion time, increases success rates, and prepares qualified students for the workforce.     

Project Goals:
Several of the original project goals were accomplished. Students who complete all of the cyber specific competencies earn the LLCC certificate as well as three industry-standard certificates.  This "course based" CBE approach delivers online courses through a Learning Management System (LMS) called Canvas. Computer science faculty were provided with one-on-one professional development to design and implement CBE courses. In lieu of a dedicated student coaching position, faculty provide essential support services to students through Repetitive and Substantive Interactions (RSI's). This program is available to all students including members of the military, rural students within LLCC's large service district, and high school dual enrollment students. This directly addresses barriers faced by under-represented students seeking to participate in a science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) field.  Courses within this certificate can also be applied to a 2-year Associate degree for transfer to another University or a degree for job placement (occupational).  At local and national levels, LLCC shares best practices of this project through a dedicated, web-based Cyber Center, conference presentations, TV and radio interviews, and community workshops.

The original project goals sought to use a "direct assessment" CBE approach that would measure over 250 competencies in one large course intended to provide evidence of student learning. Because this strategy varied significantly from the traditional "credit hour" measurement of assessment, curricular approvals would have been required from accrediting bodies.  Because the 3-year grant didn't allot time for these approvals, a course-based CBE approach with previously accredited program courses was implemented instead. To further reduce project completion time, two additional project goals were not implemented including the design of a new CBE student admission process and the development of new CBE support services in advising, financial aid, and dedicated coaching.    

CBE course characteristics:
CBE courses differ from traditional courses in several ways.  First, they use explicitly measurable program/course outcomes that serve as competencies.  A variety of assessments (i.e., multi-question bank exams, simulation activities, and labs) are mapped to key competencies that may require students to achieve a mastery level of completion (i.e., 70% or higher).  A student who doesn't reach a required mastery level can "practice" by re-studying the materials or re-taking assessments until they can. Offering a variety of assessments and allowing for repetitive learning requires some students to study course materials more frequently and diligently. 

Within each course, several assessments are grouped within Canvas module "folders".  Instead of skipping assessments or completing only selected assessments, a student is required to complete all assessments in order within a module before advancement to the next module.  As each module is completed, the next module in series is made available to a student immediately. This allows a student to work ahead of schedule and accelerates their course completion.   

Overall learning time for students with prior cybersecurity knowledge is further reduced for those who complete Prior Learning Assessments (PLA's) that are embedded within courses. Students who successfully complete a PLA at a pre-determined mastery level (i.e. 90%) can advance to the next appropriate learning module. For each PLA that is successfully mastered, completion time can be accelerated by one or more modules.   

This CBE program also requires a high level of engagement between faculty and students. Frequent engagement promotes instructor/student relationship building and can positively influence course completion. Repetitive and substantive interactions (RSI's) are provided through instructional videos, teleconferencing, mobile phone texting, or in-person meetings. Whether students are provided with warnings when they miss deadlines or are recognized for completing work on time or in advance, communication with students is important at each stage of course progression.  

Findings and Sustainability:
The total number of students pursuing this program increased each of the past four academic years.  As of spring 2022, 18 total students were participating and one student graduated.  Overall success rates for CBE Cybersecurity courses also improved when compared to traditional course designs. (Refer to the attached image.)

Computer science faculty support the continued use of CBE Cyber courses and have implemented its design for other courses they teach. CBE practices have also been shared with other LLCC academic areas for consideration in English and Workforce-related programs.   

This project also contributed to LLCC's 2019 designation as a Center for Academic Excellence (CAE) in Cybersecurity provided by the NSA and the Department of Homeland Security.  Requirements for this designation include the offering of a rigorous cyber curriculum with highly qualified instructors.  The college is preparing for CAE re-designation in 2023.


Last Modified: 07/06/2022
Modified by: Carmen R Allen
